TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic, frigid Typic Argiustolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Delson stony loam - rangeland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
A--0 to 8 inches; dark brown (7.5YR 4/2) stony loam, very dark brown (7.5YR 2/2) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure parting to moderate fine granular; soft, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many medium and fine roots; 5 percent stones; neutral; clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 15 inches thick)
BA--8 to 12 inches; dark brown (7.5YR 4/2) clay loam, very dark brown (7.5YR 2/2) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure parting to moderate coarse granular; slightly hard, friable, sticky and plastic; thin patchy clay films on faces of peds; many medium and fine roots; 5 percent stones; neutral; clear smooth boundary.  (0 to 8 inches thick)
Bt--12 to 34 inches; reddish brown (5YR 4/4) light clay, dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) moist; moderate medium prismatic structure parting to strong medium angular blocky; extremely hard, very firm, very sticky and plastic; moderately thick continuous clay films on faces of peds; few medium and coarse roots; 10 percent stones; neutral; gradual wavy boundary.  (10 to 30 inches thick)
BC--34 to 42 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) stony clay loam, dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; moderate medium hard, friable, sticky and plastic; few thin clay films on faces of peds; few coarse roots; 20 percent stones; neutral grading to mildly alkaline in lower part; gradual wavy boundary.  (4 to 12 inches thick)
C--42 to 60 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) stony clay loam, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; massive; hard, sticky and slightly plastic; 30 percent stones; mildly alkaline.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Delta County, Colorado; the NW1/4 of Sec. 24, T. 13 S., R. 93 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 40 to 46 degrees F, and mean summer soil temperature ranges from 59 to 64 degrees F.  The Delson soils are noncalcareous to depths of 40 inches or more.  Thickness of the solum ranges from 20 to 50 inches or more.  Cobbles and stones range from 0 to 35 percent with the amount typically increasing with increasing depth.  The control section is usually light clay but clay ranges from 35 to 55 percent.
The A horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 3 to 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 0 through 3.  Reaction is neutral through moderately alkaline.
The Bt horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 5YR, value of 4 to 6 dry, 3 to 6 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  Reaction is neutral through moderately alkaline.
The BC or C horizons have hue of 2.5YR through 10YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  Reaction is neutral through moderately alkaline.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Absarokee (MT), Acree (CO), Bearpaw(MT), Broiller (AZ), Danvers (MT), Herm (CO), Morapos (CO), Nortez (CO), Peninsula (CO), Pramiss (CO), Quilt (UT), Regent (ND), Reget (WY), Ricot (CO), Savage (MT), Tamaneen (MT), Tomasaki (UT), Tukuhnik (UT), and Work (MT) series. Absarokee, Acree, Bearpaw, Danvers, Morapos, Regent, Ricot, Savage, and Work soils have a consistent k horizon.  Also, Absarokee, Broiller, and Nortez soils have a lithic contact between 20 to 40 inches.  Herm soils formed in loess over fine textured alluvium and have hue of 10YR or yellower in the lower part of the Bt horizon. Danvers, Peninsula, and Tukuhnik soils have a calcic horizon.  Regent, Reget, and Pramiss soils have a paralithic contact between depths of 20 to 40 inches.  Tamaneen soils have hue of 10YR or yellower in the Bt horizon. Tomasaki soils have an argillic horizon about 40 inches thick and clayey-skeletal material below 30 inches.  Ricot soils have a lithologic discontinuity at depths ranging from 10 to 24 inches.  Quilt soils lack stones in the particle-size control section and substratum, and have less clay in the Bt horizon.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Delson soils are on alluvial fans, benches, and high mesas.  Slope gradients range from 0 to 65 percent.  The soils formed in noncalcareous moderately fine to fine textured alluvial fan materials derived from sedimentary and basaltic cap rock.  At the type location, the mean annual precipitation is 15 to 22 inches, with peak periods of precipitation occurring during the months of August through October.  The mean annual temperature is 40 to 42 degrees F.  The frost-free season is about 110 days.  Elevation ranges from 6,800 feet in the northern part of Colorado to 9,300 feet in the southern part of Colorado.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Agua Fria, Cerro, and Cochetopa soils.  Agua Fria soils have an ochric epipedon, are calcareous in the lower part of their solum, and are mesic.  Cerro soils are calcareous in the lower part of the solum and have a higher shrink-swell ratio.  Cochetopa series are pachic and are cryic.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; slow to rapid runoff; slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used primarily for grazing. Native vegetation is mainly Gambel oak, serviceberry, big sagebrush, and western wheatgrass or bluebunch wheatgrass.  Some areas are pinon-juniper woodland.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  The mountainous areas of west-central and southwestern Colorado.  The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Last updated by the state 5/93.  Diagnostic features include a mollic epipedon from 0 to 12 inches and an argillic horizon from 12 to 34 inches.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
